sentences.text: General elections were held in the Democratic Republic of the Congo on 20 December 2023. Combined elections were held for the President of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|President, 484 of the 500 members of the National Assembly of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|National Assembly, 700 of the 716 elected members of the 26 provincial assemblies, and for the first time under the new constitution, 951 members of a scaled down number of Communes of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|commune (municipal) councils. On election day CENI, in violation of electoral law, extended voting to 21 December for polling stations that had not opened on 20 December. Some polling stations stayed open on their own accord for up to six extra days.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/congo-holds-presidential-vote-after-fraught-campaign-2023-12-20/|title=Congo extends chaotic election as opposition calls for rerun|language=en|date=20 December 2023|access-date=20 December 2023|work=Reuters|first1=Sonia|last1=Rolley|first2=Yassin|last2=Kombi|first3=Fiston Mahamba|last3=Erikas|first4=Mwisi|last4=Kambale|first5=Crispin|last5=Kyala|first6=Arlette|last6=Bashizi|first7=Alessandra|last7=Prentice|first8=Bate|last8=Felix|editor1-first=Alex|editor1-last=Richardson|editor2-first=Toby|editor2-last=Chopra|editor3-first=Sandra|editor3-last=Maler|editor4-first=Daniel|editor4-last=Wallis|location=Kinshasa and Goma}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Voting extends to 2nd day in Congo elections amid fraud claims |url=https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/voting-extends-to-2nd-day-in-congo-elections-amid-fraud-claims/3088589 |access-date=2023-12-21 |website=Anadolu Ajansi |archive-date=21 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231221090310/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/voting-extends-to-2nd-day-in-congo-elections-amid-fraud-claims/3088589 |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name=":Crisis Group">{{Cite web |date=2024-01-26 |title=DR Congo: A Full Plate of Challenges after a Turbulent Vote {{!}} Crisis Group |url=https://www.crisisgroup.org/africa/great-lakes/democratic-republic-congo/dr-congo-full-plate-challenges-after-turbulent-vote |access-date=2025-02-02 |website=www.crisisgroup.org |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: The election saw President Félix Tshisekedi win in a landslide victory with 73% of the vote, far ahead of his closest rival, former Katanga Province Governor Moïse Katumbi, who only won 18%, mostly from Katanga Province|Katanga region. In the parliamentary election, while Tshisekedi's party only won 69 of the seats, his governing coalition, the Sacred Union of the Nation (USN), won nearly 450, more than 90% of the seats in the National Assembly (Democratic Republic of the Congo)|National Assembly. As Tshisekedi is dependent on his coalition, he had to compete for other key offices for his party through complex, time consuming negotiations, taking five months to form a government.

references.text: <ref name=":Crisis Group" /><ref>{{Cite web |title=DR Congo ends impasse to appoint new government |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/5/29/dr-congo-ends-impasse-to-appoint-new-government |access-date=2025-02-02 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: According to the Crisis Group, there is a fear of a wider political crisis if losing candidates or their backers do not accept the presidential results. Any crisis, while not inevitable, could worsen the already dire situation in the east.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-10-30 |title=Elections in DR Congo: Reducing the Risk of Violence |url=https://www.crisisgroup.org/africa/great-lakes/democratic-republic-congo/312-elections-en-rd-congo-limiter-les-risques-de-violence |access-date=2023-11-21 |website=www.crisisgroup.org |language=en |archive-date=21 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231121180710/https://www.crisisgroup.org/africa/great-lakes/democratic-republic-congo/312-elections-en-rd-congo-limiter-les-risques-de-violence |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: On 20 November, Fayulu advocated for transparent and impartial elections, he insisted that the Congolese "must no longer accept someone stealing their victory."

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-21 |title=Martin Fayulu à Bagata : " Nous allons avoir une armée de 500 000 personnes bien formées et bien équipée " |url=https://www.radiookapi.net/2023/11/21/actualite/politique/martin-fayulu-bagata-nous-allons-avoir-une-armee-de-500-000-personnes |access-date=2023-11-21 |website=Radio Okapi |language=fr |archive-date=21 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231121180713/https://www.radiookapi.net/2023/11/21/actualite/politique/martin-fayulu-bagata-nous-allons-avoir-une-armee-de-500-000-personnes |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |date=2023-11-19 |title=DRC: campaigning for presidential elections officially launched |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/11/19/drc-campaigning-for-presidential-elections-officially-launched/ |access-date=2023-11-21 |website=Africanews |language=en |archive-date=21 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231121180709/https://www.africanews.com/2023/11/19/drc-campaigning-for-presidential-elections-officially-launched/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text:
Selected dates from the electoral calendar:
*'''24 December 2022—17 March 2023''': Voter registration.
**'''24 December—23 January''' (30 days): Registration in Kongo Central, Kinshasa, Kwango, Kwilu Province|Kwilu, Mai-Ndombe Province|Mai-Ndombe, Province of Équateur|Equateur, Mongala, Nord-Ubangi, Sud-Ubangi and Tshuapa provinces.
**'''25 January—23 February''' (30 days): Registration in Kasaï Province|Kasaï, Kasaï-Central, Kasaï-Oriental, Lomami Province|Lomami, Sankuru Province|Sankuru, Haut-Lomami, Haut-Katanga, Lualaba Province|Lualaba and Tanganyika Province|Tanganyika provinces; also for expatriates in South Africa, Belgium, and France.
**'''16 February—17 March''' (30 days): Registration in Bas-Uélé, Haut-Uélé, Ituri, Tshopo, North Kivu, South Kivu, and Maniema provinces; also for expatriates in Canada and the United States.
*'''21 May 2023''': Publication of registration statistics per electoral district—registration totals will determine the size of the provincial assemblies and of the local councils (commune, sector, and chiefdom councils).  They are also used to apportion seats to electoral districts.
*'''23 May 2023—15 June 2023''': Proportional allocation of seats to electoral districts based on voter registration numbers; drafted and passed as a law.
*'''26 June 2023—8 October 2023''': Candidate registration.
**'''26 June—15 July''' (20 days): Candidates for the National Assembly.
**'''3 August—22 August''' (20 days): Candidates for provincial assemblies and commune councils.
**'''9 September–8 October''' (30 days): Candidates for president.
*'''19 November 2023—18 December 2023''': Electoral campaigns.
**'''19 November''': Start of 30 day campaigns for president, National Assembly, and provincial assemblies.
**'''4 December''': Start of 15 day campaigns for commune councils.
*'''20 December 2023''': Election day.
*'''20 January 2024''': Presidential swearing in ceremony.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |author1=CENI |author1-link=Independent National Electoral Commission (Democratic Republic of the Congo) |title=Synthese du Calendrier des Activites Electorales |url=https://www.radiookapi.net/sites/default/files/2022-11/synthese_calendrier_ok-1_0.pdf |publisher=Radio Okapi |access-date=30 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221130173412/https://www.radiookapi.net/sites/default/files/2022-11/synthese_calendrier_ok-1_0.pdf |archive-date=30 November 2022 |language=fr |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: The president is elected by plurality voting in one round.  For the first time, some Congolese living abroad were able to vote in the presidential election.  These were those living in Belgium, Canada, France, South Africa, and the United States.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |title=Constitution de la Republique Democratique du Congo |trans-title=The Constitution of the Democratic Republic of the Congo |date=20 January 2011 |at=Article 71 |url=https://leganet.cd/Legislation/Droit%20Public/Constitution.2011.pdf#page=23 |website=LEGANET.CD |language=fr |access-date=20 July 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190221223039/https://leganet.cd/Legislation/Droit%20Public/Constitution.2011.pdf |archive-date=21 February 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: Lumumbaville elected its first National Assembly of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|National Assembly deputy and its first deputy to the Provincial Assembly of Sankuru. This was the only new legislative district of the 2024-2028 legislature.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |title=Liste des meilleurs élus aux législatives nationales de décembre 2023 |url=https://www.ceni.cd/sites/default/files/2024-01/CENI%20RDC%20-%20Liste%20des%20Meilleurs%20Elus%20à%20la%20Deputation%20Nationale%20-%20Resultats%20Provisoires%20Election%20Leg.pdf#page=7 |trans-title= List of those elected with absolute majorities in the National Assembly elections of December 2023 |publisher=Independent National Electoral Commission (Democratic Republic of the Congo)|CENI |date= 19 January 2024 |page=7 |access-date=19 March 2024 |language=fr}}; {{cite news |title=Voici les députés provinciaux élus: Nord-Kivu, Nord-Ubangi, Sankuru, Sud-Kivu, Sud-Ubangi, Tanganyka, Tshopo et Tshuapa |url=https://www.forumdesas.net/2024/01/voici-les-deputes-provinciaux-elus-nord-kivu-nord-ubangi-sankuru-sud-kivu-sud-ubangi-tanganyka-tshopo-et-tshuapa/ |access-date=19 March 2024 |work=Forum des As |date=24 January 2024 |language=fr}}</ref>

sentences.text: A new rule requires participating political parties and Electoral alliance|alliances to contest at least 60% of the seats up for renewal in an election.  So for example, each party/alliance had to register at least 290 candidates to participate in the National Assembly election.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |title=RDC: plus de 20.000 candidatures pour 484 sièges à l'Assemblée |url=https://afrique.le360.ma/politique/rdc-plus-de-20000-candidatures-pour-484-sieges-a-lassemblee_K2RAYXJOGRDLFL46EGNY4O2474/ |access-date=6 January 2024 |work=Le360 Afrique |agency=with Agence France-Presse|AFP |date=11 August 2023 |language=fr |archive-date=25 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230925040335/https://afrique.le360.ma/politique/rdc-plus-de-20000-candidatures-pour-484-sieges-a-lassemblee_K2RAYXJOGRDLFL46EGNY4O2474/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The method by which members are elected are different in districts having more than one seat, the most common case, from those that end up with only one seat.

references.text: <ref name=kadima>{{cite news |title=Elections 2023 : 688 candidats élus provisoirement députés provinciaux (CENI) |url=https://www.radiookapi.net/2024/01/22/actualite/politique/elections-2023-688-candidats-elus-provisoirement-deputes-provinciaux |access-date=23 January 2024 |work=Radio Okapi |date=22 January 2024 |language=fr}}</ref>

sentences.text: In multiple-member districts, members are elected by open list proportional representation, with seats assigned using the largest remainder method.  Candidates who win more than half the vote in their district are automatically assigned a seat.  Otherwise, a party or independent candidate must meet an election threshold to qualify for seat assignment.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |title=RDC: Carole Agito, Matata Ponyo et Sakombi Molendo parmi les députés les mieux élus |url=https://actualite.cd/2024/01/14/rdc-carole-agito-matata-ponyo-et-sakombi-molendo-parmi-les-deputes-les-mieux-elus |access-date=20 January 2024 |work=Actualite.cd |date=14 January 2024 |language=fr}}</ref>

<ref name=kadima />  The election thresholds for the National Assembly, a provincial assembly, or a commune council are 1% of the vote nationally, 3% provincially, and 10% in the commune, respectively.<ref>{{cite web |title=Pour obtenir un siège dans les assemblées, le nombre de voix ne suffit pas |url=https://www.studiohirondellerdc.org/pour-obtenir-un-siege-dans-les-assemblees-le-nombre-de-voix-ne-suffit-pas |website=Studio Hirondelle-RDC |access-date=20 January 2024 |language=fr |date=9 January 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: The 26 official presidential candidates were:

<ref name=":0" />

sentences.text: Opinion polling is rare in the Democratic Republic of the Congo due to poor roads and lack of electricity. Nevertheless, a survey conducted by GeoPoll Socio-Political Barometer in the second quarter of 2023 found that voters expressed significant discontent with the governance under Tshisekedi, assigning him a satisfaction rating of 49.7%. Despite this, the survey also suggested that Tshisekedi would secure a second term thanks in part to perceived improvements, such as his free education initiative, and partly due to a divided opposition.

references.text: <ref name=":ISS">{{Cite web |date=2023-11-03 |title=Is DRC heading for another chaotic election? |url=https://issafrica.org/iss-today/is-drc-heading-for-another-chaotic-election |access-date=2023-11-21 |website=ISS Africa |language=en |archive-date=21 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231121180715/https://issafrica.org/iss-today/is-drc-heading-for-another-chaotic-election |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |last=Kibuacha |first=Frankline |date=2023-08-23 |title=The GeoPoll Socio-Political Barometer Survey DRC - Q2 2023 Report |url=https://www.geopoll.com/blog/drc-socio-political-barometer-q2-2023/ |access-date=2023-11-21 |website=GeoPoll |language=en-US |archive-date=21 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231121180715/https://www.geopoll.com/blog/drc-socio-political-barometer-q2-2023/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: An earlier 2022 poll by the same group found unemployment and insecurity to be the most cited dysfunctional areas, closely followed by the state of the country's roads and rising prices. On the other hand, free education was found to be the most favorable policy.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Angus-Hammond |first=Matt |date=2022-12-23 |title=Democratic Republic of the Congo - The GeoPoll Socio-Political Barometer Survey - Report Preview |url=https://www.geopoll.com/blog/socio-political-barometer-democratic-republic-of-the-congo-report-preview/ |access-date=2023-11-21 |website=GeoPoll |language=en-US |archive-date=21 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231121180711/https://www.geopoll.com/blog/socio-political-barometer-democratic-republic-of-the-congo-report-preview/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: While the lead-up to the election was generally calm, several violent incidents were reported. On 14 July 2023, Chérubin Okende Senga, spokesperson for ENSEMBLE and former transport minister, was fatally shot in Kinshasa. The murder, described by Katumbi as a "political assassination," led to legal action by Senga's relatives in Brussels, accusing the head of the DRC's military intelligence of involvement. Later in the year, a Katumbi rally in Moanda, Democratic Republic of the Congo|Moanda was broken up by live rounds, injuring several people. The provincial government blamed Katumbi's guards, stating that they fired warning shots after the crowd grew rowdy. Katumbi blamed the police.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-07-14 |title=La Prospérité : " Chérubin Okende : les Evêques catholiques exigent la tête de Caïn ! " |url=https://www.radiookapi.net/2023/07/14/actualite/revue-de-presse/la-prosperite-cherubin-okende-les-eveques-catholiques-exigent |access-date=2024-01-18 |website=Radio Okapi |language=fr}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Relatives of slain Congolese politician file suit in Belgium against Intelligence chief |url=https://www.brusselstimes.com/787972/relatives-of-slain-congolese-politician-file-suit-in-belgium-against-intelligence-chief |access-date=2024-01-18 |website=The Brussels Times |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Christensen |first1=Sofia |last2=Kasongo |first2=Ange |title=Congo opposition candidate suspends presidential campaign after violence |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/congo-opposition-candidate-suspends-presidential-campaign-after-violence-2023-12-13/ |website=Reuters}}</ref>

sentences.text: On November 28, during Katumbi's march in Kindu, UDPS supporters threw stones at Dido Kakisingi, leader of ENSEMBLE's Maniema youth league, to then be run over and killed by a truck belonging to the campaign team of Maniema Governor Afani Idrissa Mangala. After his killing, more UDPS supporters were seen throwing stones, and gunshots were recorded, presumably from the Congolese National Police. Two people were sentenced to five years in jail in relation to the killing of Kakisingi.

references.text: <ref name="hrw kindu">{{Cite web | website=HRW|language=en-GB| url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2023/12/16/dr-congo-electoral-violence-threatens-vote|title=DR Congo: Electoral Violence Threatens Vote|date=2023-12-16|access-date=2024-12-20}}</ref>

<ref name="bellingcat kindu">{{Cite web |last1=Stoecklin |first1=Sarah|last2=Giannardi|first2=Riccardo |date=2024-12-10 |title=Retracing the Congolese March Where Dido Kakisingi was Killed |url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/2024/12/10/retracing-the-congolese-march-where-dido-kakisingi-was-killed/ |website=Bellingcat |language=en-GB|access-date=2024-12-20}}</ref>

sentences.text: At least 19 deaths, including two candidates, have been attributed to election-related violence.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-23 |title=Carter Center preliminary statement on the Democratic Republic of the Congo general elections - Democratic Republic of the Congo {{!}} ReliefWeb |url=https://reliefweb.int/report/democratic-republic-congo/carter-center-preliminary-statement-democratic-republic-congo-general-elections |access-date=2024-01-18 |website=reliefweb.int |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: CENI was reportedly woefully underprepared for the election. Due to the state of the country's roads compared to its size and the lack of funding, CENI was forced to resort to doing almost everything via plane. As transporting by air is costly, CENI had to get Egypt to send two Lockheed C-130 Hercules|C-130 Hercules planes to help deliver ballot papers at the last moment. Additionally, CENI begged the UN to use its aircraft.

references.text: <ref name=":4">{{Cite web |last=Niarchos |first=Nicolas |title='A Simulacrum of Elections' {{!}} Nicolas Niarchos |url=https://www.nybooks.com/online/2024/01/16/a-simulacrum-of-elections/ |access-date=2024-01-18 |website=The New York Review of Books |date=16 January 2024 |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Controversially, the election necessitated an extension into a second day, a move which was declared illegal by local observers and civil society, and parts of the country were still casting ballots five days after election day.

references.text: <ref name=":5">{{Cite web |title=DR Congo's President Tshisekedi sworn in for second term amid disputes |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/1/20/dr-congos-president-tshisekedi-sworn-in-for-second-term-amid-disputes |access-date=2024-01-20 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Tafi Mhaka, in an opinion piece for Al Jazeera Media Network|Aljazeera, described the elections as "Sham election|shambolic," calling for the Southern African Development Community to uphold electoral standards in every single member country.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Mhaka |first=Tafi |title=DR Congo's shambolic election should be a wake-up call for the SADC |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/opinions/2024/1/18/dr-congos-shambolic-election-should-be-a-wake-up-call-for-the-sadc |access-date=2024-01-20 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Alternatively, Albert Kasanda, in his piece for The Conversation (website)|The Conversation, partially attributes the opposition's failure to unite behind a single candidate and their campaign strategies, compared to Tshisekedi, who had the backing of major political figures which provided him a broad territorial network and a foothold in various regions of the country.

references.text: <ref name=":conversation">{{Cite web |last=Kasanda |first=Albert |date=2024-01-17 |title=DR Congo's election – the key to Félix Tshisekedi's victory |url=http://theconversation.com/dr-congos-election-the-key-to-felix-tshisekedis-victory-221143 |access-date=2024-01-20 |website=The Conversation |language=en-US}}</ref>

sentences.text:
| source     = Independent National Electoral Commission (Democratic Republic of the Congo)|CENI as amended by the Constitutional Court of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Constitutional Court
}}

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |title=Résultats des élections combinées du 20 décembre 2023 |trans-title= Results of the combined elections of 20 December 2023 |url=https://cartographie.ceni.cd/scrutins.html |publisher=Independent National Electoral Commission (Democratic Republic of the Congo)|CENI |access-date=15 January 2024 |language=fr}}</ref>

<ref name=CC>{{cite AV media |people= |date=9 January 2024 |title=Audience publique du 09 janvier 2024 – Contentieux des résultats de la présidentielle  |trans-title=Public Hearing of January 09, 2024 - Litigation over the presidential election results |type=video |language=fr |url=https://www.facebook.com/CourconstitutionnelleRDCongo/videos/677242114610182/ |access-date=13 January 2024 |archive-url= |archive-date= |time=1:47:00 |publisher=Constitutional Court of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Constitutional Court |via=Facebook}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{wide image|2023 Democratic Republic of the Congo parliamentary election by district.svg|600x600px|Map displaying seats won by party/alliance}}
Prominent opposition figure Kabila's People's Party for Reconstruction and Democracy and his coalition, the Common Front for Congo (FFC), just like with the presidential election, did not partake in the electoral process, citing unmet demands such as representation of the FCC within CENI, an independent, balanced constitutional court, a consensual electoral law that guarantees greater transparency, security for opposition members, and the restoration of security in the eastern part of the DRC as well as in the province of Mai-Ndombe Province|Mai-Ndombe. Another prominent opposition figure, Fayulu, blocked his party from participating in the parliamentary election.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-10-16 |title=Kinshasa : le FCC réitère les préalables à sa participation au processus électoral |url=https://www.radiookapi.net/2023/10/16/actualite/societe/kinshasa-le-fcc-reitere-les-prealables-sa-participation-au-processus |access-date=2025-02-01 |website=Radio Okapi |language=fr}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-01-26 |title=DR Congo: A Full Plate of Challenges after a Turbulent Vote {{!}} Crisis Group |url=https://www.crisisgroup.org/africa/great-lakes/democratic-republic-congo/dr-congo-full-plate-challenges-after-turbulent-vote |access-date=2025-02-01 |website=www.crisisgroup.org |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: The provisional results, initially due on January 3, 2024, were delayed by 10 days due to reported fraud and irregularities denounced by CENI. Later, on 4 February, 2024, the CENI published the remaining provisional results of the elections for national and provincial deputies in the electoral districts of Budjala, Bomongo, Ilebo, Kikwit, Kole, Makanza and Mobayi-Mbongo. According to the provisional results, 44 parties and/or political groupings had met the threshold for representation in the National Assembly. The results came from 177 constituencies, excluding Masimanimba in Kwilu Province|Kwilu and Yakoma in Nord-Ubangi as they were annulled for fraud, and the territories of Masisi Territory|Masisi and Rutshuru Territory|Rutshuru in North Kivu and Kwamouth in Maï-Ndombe, where elections were not held due to the activism of armed groups. Additionally, 82 candidates for the national, provincial and local legislative election had their candidacy invalidated for electoral fraud and other illicit acts.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |author=Joslin Lomba |date=2024-01-14 |title=Proclamation des résultats législatives : Voici les 44 partis et regroupements politiques ayant atteint le seuil |url=https://www.mediacongo.net/article-actualite-131806_proclamation_des_resultats_legislatives_voici_les_44_partis_et_regroupements_politiques_ayant_atteint_le_seuil.html |access-date=2024-01-14 |website=mediacongo.net}}</ref>

<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite web |author=Bruno Nsaka |date=2024-01-13 |title=Publication des résultats des législatives nationales : Ce qu'il faut savoir avant l'heure H |url=https://actualite.cd/2024/01/13/publication-des-resultats-des-legislatives-nationales-ce-quil-faut-savoir-avant-lheure-h |access-date=2024-01-14 |website=Actualite.cd |language=fr}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-01-08 |title=L'Avenir : "Crash électoral : La CENI invalide 82 candidats " |url=https://www.radiookapi.net/2024/01/11/actualite/revue-de-presse/lavenir-crash-electoral-la-ceni-invalide-82-candidats |access-date=2024-01-14 |website=Radio Okapi |language=fr}}</ref>

sentences.text: Matata Ponyo Mapon, Constant Mutamba, Jean-Claude Baende and Adolphe Muzito, who also stood in the presidential election, were elected in Kindu, Lubao, Mbandaka and Kikwit respectively, while a large number of the president's allies, including the two presidents of the houses of parliament: Christophe Mboso and Modeste Bahati Lukwebo|Bahati Lukuebo, Prime Minister Sama Lukonde, and the candidate deputy prime ministers Vital Kamerhe, Jean-Pierre Lihau and Christophe Lutundula, won their seats once again.

sentences.text: On 6 January 2024, Katumbi released a statement disputing the results of the election on the grounds of "massive fraud and treachery" and calling for the resignation of Denis Kadima, the head of the Independent National Electoral Commission (Democratic Republic of the Congo)|Independent National Electoral Commission. Two days later, his party stated that he had been placed under house arrest, with a spokesman reporting the presence of "heavily armed soldiers traveling in armoured vehicles surrounding his house". The security forces were subsequently ordered to withdraw by the provincial governor Jacques Kyabula Katwe.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newtimes.co.rw/article/13626/news/africa/dr-congo-opposition-politician-moise-katumbi-blocked-from-leaving-home|title=DR Congo opposition politician Moïse Katumbi blocked from leaving home|newspaper=The New Times|location=Rwanda|date=9 January 2024|access-date=10 January 2024|archive-date=10 January 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240110005622/https://www.newtimes.co.rw/article/13626/news/africa/dr-congo-opposition-politician-moise-katumbi-blocked-from-leaving-home|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-67920501|title=Moïse Katumbi in DR Congo: Troops surrounded poll loser's home|publisher=BBC News|date=9 January 2024|access-date=10 January 2024|archive-date=10 January 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240110010103/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-67920501|url-status=live}}</ref>
